{{Unsourced|date=May 2013}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:AndySchillinger.jpg|right|thumb|Andrew Schillinger]] --> '''Andrew Peter Schillinger''', played by [[Frederick Koehler]], is a fictional character in the [[HBO]] drama ''[[Oz (TV series)|Oz]]''.
==Character overview== ''Prisoner 99S333. Convicted February 16, 1999 - Murder in the second degree, possession of narcotics. Sentence: 50 years, up for parole in 20.''
Raised with his brother [[Hank Schillinger|Hank]] by his [[racism|racist]] grandfather Heinrick and equally racist father [[Vern Schillinger]], Andrew has supported the ideology of the [[The Aryan Brotherhood in Oz|Aryan Brotherhood]] throughout his whole life. As a result, he lands in Oz for his part in a [[hate crime]] — he and a few friends murder a black man by dragging him from the back of a pickup truck (very similar to the [[James Byrd, Jr.|James Byrd]] murder in [[Jasper, Texas]]).
Andrew, however, has a problem that makes his commitment to the brotherhood questionable: he is a full-blown [[heroin]] addict. Andrew's addiction causes problems between him and his father in Oz that eventually result in his death.
When he and Hank were 12 and 10 years old (respectively), Vern nearly murdered a black drug dealer from whom they were trying to buy [[marijuana]], the crime for which he was incarcerated.
==Season 3== Andrew arrives in Oz for his part in a hate crime (murdering a black man). When in Oz, he looks for drugs immediately and is supplied by [[Irish people|Irish]] inmate [[Ryan O'Reily]]. He has been moved to Emerald City purposefully by unit manager [[Tim McManus]], who hates his father [[Vernon Schillinger]], the head of the Aryan Brotherhood, serving time in Oz's unit B. When Schillinger begs [[Warden Glynn]] to move Andrew to Unit B, Glynn refuses in order to punish him.
In the cafeteria, Vern sees Andrew drugged out courtesy of O'Reilly and then gets guard [[Len Lopresti]] to take him to the isolation ward for using heroin. Because of Andrew's addiction, Vern tells the brotherhood to ignore him until he is drug free, as the Aryans in Oz oppose the use of drugs. At the same time, the other inmates, including the blacks, who are sickened by his crime, do not make any attempts to kill or [[rape]] Andrew out of fear of Vern's wrath. When Andrew gets back to Emerald City, he is cut off from O'Reilly's drug connections, who claims that Andrew is burning through his supply too fast. O'Reilly then points out that the other dealers in Oz are of other races, who Andrew refuses to buy from.
In drug rehab, Andrew is very disrespectful to [[Sister Peter Marie|Sister Pete]] and his attitude starts a fight between inmates [[Chris Keller]] and [[Tobias Beecher]], which they later reveal was staged. Beecher then befriends Andrew, a move that McManus, the staff, and other inmates question, given Beecher's longstanding feud with Vern. Over a period of time, Beecher helps Andrew beat his addiction, and Andrew befriends O'Reily and Keller as well. As all three are looking to exact revenge on Vern, Schillinger becomes worried that his son will be murdered or raped by any of the three, especially after Beecher taunts Schillinger in the mail room. Meanwhile, as Andrew gets clean, he starts to question the ideology taught to him by his family.
In the cafeteria, Vern speaks with Andrew and hugs him, happy that he is drug free. He claims that he wants have a better relationship with him, but Andrew rejects him, angered by everything that his father stands for. Vern hits him and Andrew retaliates, until the guards, led by Lopresti, take Andrew to the hole. Vern, heartbroken that his son has renounced him, arranges for the guards to take Andrew a package of heroin, as a way of "renouncing" him. Lopresti delivers the heroin to the hole. Andrew at first resists, throwing the package away, but breaks down and then [[drug overdose|overdoses]] on it. As the guards carry Andrew's personal effects out of his cell, Beecher, O'Reilly, and Keller reveal that this was their plan all along.
==Season 6== His spirit, along with Hank's, narrate the episode "4giveness".
===Murders committed===
* '''Unknown black man''' - Murdered by Andrew, then got 50 years in prison.

{{for|the wrestler|Barrett Brown (wrestler)}} {{quotefarm|date=February 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Barrett Brown | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Barrett Brown 2017.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Barrett Brown in [[Denton, Texas]], 2017 | birth_name = Barrett Lancaster Brown | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1981|08|14}} | birth_place = [[Dallas, Texas]] | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | citizenship = | alma_mater = | occupation = Journalist, Activist | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = [https://web.archive.org/web/20150626110357/http://wiki.project-pm.org/wiki/Main_Page Project PM] | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | website = {{Plainlist | * [https://freebarrettbrown.org/ FreeBarrettBrown.org] }} | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Barrett Lancaster Brown''' (born August 14, 1981) is an American journalist, essayist and [[satirist]]. He founded Project PM, a research collaboration and [[wiki]], to facilitate analysis of the troves of hacked emails and other [[Internet leak|leaked information]] concerning the inner workings of the cyber-[[military-industrial complex]].{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/barrett-brown-faces-105-years-in-jail-20130905 |title=Barrett Brown Faces 105 Years in Jail |last=Zaitchik |first=Alexander |date=5 September 2013 |website=Rolling Stone |publisher=Rolling Stone |access-date=2 December 2016}} In January 2015, Brown was sentenced to 63 months in federal prison for the crimes of [[accessory after the fact]], [[obstruction of justice]], and [[threatening the government officials of the United States#Other civil servants|threatening a federal officer]] stemming from the FBI's investigation into the [[2012 Stratfor email leak]]. Prosecutors had previously brought other charges associated with his sharing of an [[Hyperlink#Legal issues|HTTP link]] to the leaked Stratfor data, but those charges were dropped in 2014.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/09/business/media/a-journalist-agitator-facing-prison-over-a-link.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 | title=A Journalist-Agitator Facing Prison Over a Link | work=[[The New York Times]] | author=David Carr | date=September 9, 2013 | accessdate=December 19, 2013 }} {{cite news | url=http://www.thenation.com/article/174851/strange-case-barrett-brown | title=The Strange Case of Barrett Brown | work=[[The Nation]] | author=Peter Ludlow | date=June 18, 2013 | accessdate=December 19, 2013 }} {{cite news | url=http://www.dmlp.org/blog/2013/adding-105-charges-against-barrett-brown | title=Adding up to 105: The Charges Against Barrett Brown | work=[[Digital Media Law Project]] | author=Kristin Bergman | date=August 6, 2013 | accessdate=December 13, 2013 }} {{Cite web|title=A Dispatch From Outside the Prison Holding Barrett Brown|date=March 8, 2014|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/a-dispatch-from-outside-barrett-browns-prison}} As part of his sentence, Brown was also required to pay almost $900,000 to [[Stratfor]].{{cite news | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/01/31/my-post-cyberpunk-indentured-servitude.html | title=My Post Cyberpunk Indentured Servitude | work=[[The Daily Beast]] | author=Barrett Brown | date=January 31, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015}} Prior to 2011, Brown had ties with the [[hacktivist]] collective [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]]. ==Early life and education== Brown was born in [[Dallas, Texas]], to Robert Brown and Karen Lancaster, who later divorced. He grew up in Dallas and exhibited an early interest in writing and journalism, creating his own newspapers on his family's computer while attending [[Preston Hollow Elementary School]].Rogers, Tim. "[http://www.dmagazine.com/publications/d-magazine/2011/april/how-barrett-brown-helped-overthrow-the-government-of-tunisia?single=1 Barrett Brown is Anonymous]." ''[[D Magazine]]''. April 2011. Retrieved on May 30, 2014. He went on to contribute to his school newspapers, and interned at several weekly newspapers during his teenage years. He attended the [[Episcopal School of Dallas]] through his sophomore year of high school, then spent his would-be junior year in [[Tanzania]] with his father who was residing there on business. While in Africa, Brown completed high school online through a [[Texas Tech University]] program, earning college credits as well as his high school diploma. In 2000 he enrolled at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] and spent two semesters taking writing courses before leaving school to pursue a full-time career as a freelance writer.{{cite news | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/barrett-brown-faces-105-years-in-jail-20130905 | title=Barrett Brown: America's Least Likely Political Prisoner | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | author=[[Alexander Zaitchik]] | date={{date|2013-09-05|mdy}} | accessdate={{date|2013-10-10|mdy}} }} {{cite news |url=http://www.dmagazine.com/Home/D_Magazine/2011/April/How_Barrett_Brown_Helped_Overthrow_the_Government_of_Tunisia.aspx |title=Barrett Brown is Anonymous |work=[[D Magazine]] |author=Tim Rogers |date={{date|2011-03-23|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2013-10-09|mdy}} |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012052347/http://www.dmagazine.com/Home/D_Magazine/2011/April/How_Barrett_Brown_Helped_Overthrow_the_Government_of_Tunisia.aspx |archivedate=October 12, 2013 |df=mdy }} {{cite news | url=http://discomfit.blogspot.com/2015/05/h3ll3nd3r-authoritarian-governments.html | title =The Authoritarian Government's Maligning of Journalist, Polemicist Barrett Brown | work=Discomfit Magazine | author=Hellender | date={{date|2015-05-19|mdy}} | accessdate={{date|2015-05-21|mdy}} }} ==Journalism== Brown served as the director of communications for ''Enlighten the Vote'', an [[Atheism|atheist]] [[Political action committee|PAC]] that provides financial and strategic assistance to political candidates that advocate strict enforcement of the [[Establishment Clause]].{{cite web|author=Ryan Gallagher |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/mar/20/barrett-brown-anonymous-pr-federal-target |title=How Barrett Brown went from Anonymous's PR to federal target|work=The Guardian|accessdate=September 6, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/panelists/51376-barrett-brown |title=Barrett Brown |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=August 1, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818044050/http://www.businessweek.com/panelists/51376-barrett-brown |archivedate=August 18, 2013 |df=mdy }} In 2010, Brown began work on his crowdsourced investigation wiki, Project PM. Brown has written that the main goals of Project PM are to increase the positive influence of what he calls "the more capable segments of the blogosphere", while reducing the negative influence of well-regarded mainstream pundits, who may have political agendas not compatible with public interest. It was his aim that the wiki Project PM be established by way of the deliberate generation of critical mass of work and following among dependable bloggers in such a manner as that segments of the traditional media will be prompted or even forced to address critical issues in their own methods and means of reportage. A further and experimental aim of Project PM is also to develop a communicational schematic which could provide bloggers, reporters and any other concerned [[Citizen journalist]] with the best possible feed of raw information by which to produce content. On the aim of Project PM, Brown has stated:
The institutions and structures that have developed over the past two decades of accelerating public internet use have had what we reasonably describe as a wholesome effect on information flow. But the information age is a work in progress, and thus there are potential improvements to be made. More importantly, there are improvements that can be made by an initially small number of influential participants working in coordination. The purpose of Project PM is to implement these solutions to the extent that participants are collectively able to do so, as well as to demonstrate the beneficial effects of these solutions to others that they might be spurred to recreate or even build upon them independently of our own efforts.{{cite web|author=Barrett Brown|url=http://trueslant.com/barrettbrown/2010/03/24/project-pm/|title=The Great Pundit Hunt – Barrett Brown at True/Slant|publisher=True/Slant|date=March 24, 2010|accessdate=July 24, 2014}}
In June 2011, he and Project PM released an exclusive report about a surveillance contract called "Romas/COIN" which was discovered in e-mails hacked from HBGary by Anonymous. It consisted of sophisticated data-mining techniques leveraging mobile software and aimed at Arab countries.{{cite web|author=Barrett Brown|url=http://wiki.project-pm.org/wiki/Romas/COIN|title=Romas/COIN|publisher=Project PM|date=June 22, 2011|accessdate=January 31, 2014}}{{cite web|author=Barrett Brown|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/jun/22/hacking-anonymous|title=A sinister cyber-surveillance scheme exposed|work=The Guardian|date=June 22, 2011|accessdate=January 31, 2014}} In November 2011, Brown said that 75 names of members of the [[Zetas (Mexico)|Zetas]] drug cartel would be released if a member of the Anonymous group who had been kidnapped was not set free.{{cite news | url=http://frontburner.dmagazine.com/2011/11/04/barrett-brown-vs-the-zetas/ | title=Barrett Brown vs. The Zetas | work=D Magazine | author=Tim Rogers | date=November 4, 2011 | accessdate=October 9, 2013 }} Brown says the member was then released and that there was a truce between him and the drug cartel for the moment. Others have said the kidnapping was fake.{{cite news | url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/technology/2011/11/anonymous-barrett-brown-armed-mexican-drug-cartels/44578/ | title=Anonymous and the Zetas Cartel Declare a Truce | work=[[The Atlantic]] | author=Adam Clark Estes | date=November 4, 2011 | accessdate=October 9, 2013 }} On January 18, 2012, Brown was interviewed by the English language Russian news network [[Russia Today|RT]] about the cyber attacks by Anonymous and the temporary blackout of the US government websites WhiteHouse.Gov, DoJ.gov and FBI.gov.{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/usa/anonymous-barrettbrown-sopa-megaupload-241/ |title=Internet strikes back: Anonymous' Operation Megaupload explained |publisher=RT|date=January 20, 2012 |accessdate=October 9, 2013}} On March 6, 2012, he confirmed on [[Twitter]] that the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] raided his residence after receiving information from [[Hector Xavier Monsegur]] (also known by the online pseudonym Sabu), the founder of [[LulzSec]].{{cite news | url=https://gizmodo.com/5890961/anonymous-reacts-to-sabus-betrayal-of-lulzsec | title=Anonymous Reacts to Sabu's Betrayal of LulzSec | work=[[Gizmodo]] | author=Adrian Covert | date=March 6, 2012 | accessdate=October 9, 2013 }} In early January 2014, it was announced that his second book, begun in 2006, will be published. According to his legal defense website
The book was originally titled ''Hot, Fat, and Clouded: The Amazing and Amusing Failures of America’s Chattering Class'' and consisted of his attack on the ubiquitous newspaper columnists and media pundits whom he argues are undeservedly influential and able to form public opinion. … We are excited to announce that we have rescued the book from its fate and that it will soon see the light of day. Newly titled as ''Keep Rootin’ for Putin: Establishment Pundits and the Twilight of American Competence'', the text become available as an eBook in the spring of 2014 for donors to his legal defense fund.{{cite news|last=Rogers|first=Tim|title=Barrett Brown Book Will Be Released After All|url=http://frontburner.dmagazine.com/2014/01/06/barrett-brown-book-will-be-released-after-all/|accessdate=January 8, 2014|newspaper=D Magazine|date=January 6, 2014}}
From September 2012, during his incarceration, Brown wrote a series of columns for [[D Magazine]] titled "The Barrett Brown Review of Arts and Letters and Jail".{{cite web|url=http://frontburner.dmagazine.com/author/barrettbrown/ |title=The Barrett Brown Review of Arts and Letters and Jail |work=D Magazine}} In 2015 he transitioned from [[D Magazine|D]] to [[The Intercept]].{{cite web|url=https://freebarrettbrown.org/2015/07/08/announcement-barrett-brown-is-courages-fifth-beneficiary/ |title=Announcement: Barrett Brown is Courage’s fifth beneficiary}}{{cite web|url=http://frontburner.dmagazine.com/2015/07/10/barrett-brown-gives-d-magazine-the-middle-finger-leaves-frontburner-for-more-fertile-greenwald-grounds/ |title=Barrett Brown Gives D Magazine the Middle Finger, Leaves FrontBurner for More Fertile Greenwald Grounds |author=Tim Rogers |work=[[D Magazine]] |date=Jul 10, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2015/07/16/barrett-brown-review-prison/ |title=A Visit to the Sweat Lodge |author=Barrett Brown |date=July 16, 2015 |work=[[The Intercept]]}} In 2016 The Intercept won a [[National Magazine Award]] for three of Barrett's columns.{{cite web|url=http://www.magazine.org/asme/ellie-awards-2016-winners-announced |title=Ellie Awards 2016 Winners Announced |work=American Society of Magazine Editors |date=February 3, 2016 |accessdate=February 3, 2013}} He has written for ''[[The Daily Beast]]'',http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/01/31/my-post-cyberpunk-indentured-servitude.html''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/contributors/barrett-brown |title=Barrett Brown |work=Vanity Fair |accessdate=September 6, 2013}} ''[[True/Slant]]'',{{cite web |url=http://trueslant.com/barrettbrown/ |title=Barrett Brown|publisher=True/Slant |accessdate=October 10, 2013}} ''[[The Huffington Post]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/barrett-brown |title=Barrett Brown |work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=September 6, 2013}} ''[[The Guardian]]'',{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/profile/barrett-brown |title=Barrett Brown |work=The Guardian|accessdate=September 6, 2013}} and other publications. ==Association with Anonymous== Some media outlets have presented Brown as a spokesperson for [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]], a label he disputes.{{cite news | url=https://www.vice.com/en_ca/read/we-spoke-to-barrett-brown-from-prison | work=[[VICE (magazine)|VICE]] | title=We Spoke To Barrett Brown From Prison | author=Patrick McGuire | date=March 1, 2013 | accessdate=November 11, 2013 }} He has appeared in the documentaries ''[[We Are Legion]]'', ''[[Terms and Conditions May Apply]]'', and ''[[The Hacker Wars]]''.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5524714/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t18 |title=Barrett Brown (II) |publisher=Internet Movie Database |date=September 29, 2014 |accessdate=September 29, 2014}}https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/17/movies/the-hacker-wars-a-documentary-about-prosecutions.html Brown has said he renounced his links with the group in 2011.{{cite news | url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2011/05/why-anonymous-spokesman-is-leaving-the-group/ | title=Prolific "spokesman" for Anonymous leaves the hacker group | work=[[Ars Technica]] | author=Nate Anderson | date=May 6, 2011 | accessdate=October 9, 2013 }} It was also reported in 2011 that Brown and Anon alumnus Gregg Housh had landed a six-figure deal with Amazon for a book tentatively titled ''Anonymous: Tales From Inside The Accidental Cyberwar''.{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2057884/Anonymous-spokesman-Barrett-Brown-lands-figure-book-deal.html | title=Cashing in as the face of Anonymous: Hacking group spokesman lands a six figure book deal | work=[[Daily Mail]] | author=Hannah Roberts| date=November 5, 2011 | accessdate=October 10, 2013 }} ==Arrest and trial== On March 6, 2012, the FBI executed search warrants at Brown's apartment and his mother's house seeking evidence of alleged crimes. The items to be seized included "Records relating to HBGary, Infragard, Endgame Systems, Anonymous, LulzSec, IRC Chats, Twitter, wiki.echelon2.org, and pastebin.com." Agents took possession of his laptop computers. "I suspect that the FBI is working off of incorrect information," Brown told a reporter.{{cite news | url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mhastings/exclusive-fbi-escalates-war-on-anonymous | title=Exclusive: FBI Escalates War On Anonymous | work=BuzzFeed | author=Michael Hastings | date=April 24, 2012 | accessdate=December 28, 2013 }} On September 12, 2012, Brown was arrested in [[Dallas County, Texas]] for threatening an [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent in a [[YouTube]] video. His arrest occurred as he left a computer linked to [[Tinychat]] in which the raid could be heard in the background.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-YYhy4JQpnk |title=Barrett Brown Busted |publisher=YouTube |date=September 12, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2013}} Brown has talked publicly about his history of using heroin and he was going through withdrawal{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/13/barrett-brown-arrested-fo_n_1881535.html| title=Barrett Brown Arrested: Former Anonymous Spokesman Taken Into Custody After Threatening FBI Agent| work=[[The Huffington Post]]| author=Gerry Smith| date=September 13, 2012|accessdate=September 10, 2013}}{{cite news | url=https://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2013/09/barrett-brown-105-years-jail-posting-link | title=105 Years in Jail for Posting a Link? | work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | author=Kevin Drum | date=September 9, 2013 | accessdate=September 10, 2013 }} on the day of his arrest. A magistrate denied [[bail]], and therefore he was kept in [[remand (detention)|pre-trial detention]], because he was "a danger to the safety of the community and a risk of flight."{{cite news | url=http://crimeblog.dallasnews.com/2013/04/u-s-attorneys-office-asks-judge-to-toss-motion-to-intervene-in-the-case-of-detained-hacktivist-barrett-brown.html | title=U.S. Attorney’s Office asks judge to toss motion to intervene in the case of detained hacktivist Barrett Brown | work=[[Dallas News]] | author=Robert Wilonsky| date=April 3, 2013 | accessdate=October 9, 2013 }} On September 24, 2012, a [[Pastebin]] post appeared titled "Barrett Brown – Communiqué from Prison 9/20/12", in which Brown thanked supporters, described the insufficient medical treatment he received after having his ribs injured during his arrest, and acknowledged some past mistakes. The missive concludes, "I will personally thank everyone on the outside who has helped me and this movement particularly at this critical time, when I have regained the freedom that I did nothing to lose. For now, and until that time, it is war, on paper as always, but war."{{cite web|url=http://pastebin.com/TDY5gUS4 |title=Barrett Brown – Communiqué from Prison 9/20/12 |publisher=Pastebin.com |accessdate=September 6, 2013}} On October 3, 2012, a federal [[grand jury]] indictment was returned against Brown on charges of threats, conspiracy and retaliation against a federal law enforcement officer. Various tweets, YouTube uploads and comments made by Brown before his arrest were cited as support within the indictment.{{cite news | url=http://crimeblog.dallasnews.com/2012/10/feds-indict-self-proclaimed-anonymous-spokesman-on-retaliation-conspiracy-charges.html | title=Feds indict self-proclaimed Anonymous spokesman Barrett Brown on retaliation, conspiracy charges | work=Dallas News | author=Avi Selk| date=October 4, 2012 | accessdate=October 9, 2013 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/txn/PressRelease/2012/OCT2012/oct4brown_barrett_ind.html |title=Federal Grand Jury Charges Dallas Resident With Making An Internet Threat And Other Felony Offenses |publisher=Justice.gov |date=October 4, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901204849/http://www.justice.gov/usao/txn/PressRelease/2012/OCT2012/oct4brown_barrett_ind.html |archivedate=September 1, 2013 |df=mdy }} He later entered a plea of not guilty to all three counts.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} On December 4, 2012, Brown was indicted on an additional 12 federal charges related to the December 25, 2011 [[Hacker (computer security)|hack]] of Austin-based [[Private intelligence agency|private intelligence company]] [[Stratfor]] carried out by [[Jeremy Hammond]].{{cite news | url=http://crimeblog.dallasnews.com/2012/12/new-federal-indictment-lists-12-more-charges-against-barrett-brown-once-the-self-proclaimed-spokesman-for-anonymous.html/ | title=New federal indictment lists 12 more charges against Barrett Brown | work=Dallas News | author=Robert Wilonsky| date=October 7, 2012 | accessdate=October 9, 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/txn/PressRelease/2012/DEC2012/dec7brown_barrett_ind.html |title=Dallas Man Associated With Anonymous Hacking Group Faces Additional Federal Charges |publisher=Justice.gov |accessdate=September 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825061335/http://www.justice.gov/usao/txn/PressRelease/2012/DEC2012/dec7brown_barrett_ind.html |archivedate=August 25, 2013 |df=mdy }} A trove of millions of Stratfor emails from the hack, including authentication information for thousands of credit card accounts, was shared by the hacker collective [[LulzSec]] with [[whistleblower]] site [[WikiLeaks]] (main article: [[2012 Stratfor email leak]]). While Hammond pleaded guilty and received the maximum sentence of ten years in federal prison for the hack itself,{{cite news|title=Jeremy Hammond, hacker for Anonymous, sentenced to 10 years|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/jeremy-hammond-hacker-for-anonymous-sentenced-to-10-years/2013/11/15/1935198c-4e33-11e3-9890-a1e0997fb0c0_story.html|accessdate=December 1, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=November 15, 2013}} Brown faced up to 45 years in federal prison for allegedly sharing a [[Hyperlink#Legal issues|link]] to the data as part of Project PM, after a presumed FBI entrapment maneuver.{{cite web|author=Robert McMillan|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/12/fbi-charges-barrett-brown/ |title=Feds Charge Anonymous Spokesperson for Sharing Hacked Stratfor Credit Cards |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=December 7, 2012 |accessdate=December 16, 2013}}) Attorney [[Jesselyn Radack]] has raised connections between Brown's case, and that of her client [[Peter Van Buren]], whom the State Department sought to prosecute over a link on his personal blog to a Wikileaks document. Two online commentators on internet security issues criticized the charges against Brown.{{cite news |url=http://gawker.com/5966757/former-anonymous-spokesman-barrett-brown-indicted-for-sharing-a-link-to-stolen-credit-card-information |title=Former Anonymous Spokesman Barrett Brown Indicted For Sharing a Link to Stolen Credit Card Data |work=[[Gawker]] |author=Adrian Chen |date=December 7, 2012 |accessdate=October 9, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130920233252/http://gawker.com/5966757/former-anonymous-spokesman-barrett-brown-indicted-for-sharing-a-link-to-stolen-credit-card-information |archivedate=September 20, 2013 |df=mdy }}{{cite news |url=http://www.livescience.com/25398-barrett-brown-indictment-editorial.html |title=Editorial: If Barrett Brown's Guilty, Then So Am I |work=[[LiveScience]] |author=Paul Wagenseil |date=December 12, 2012 |accessdate=October 9, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003124952/http://www.livescience.com/25398-barrett-brown-indictment-editorial.html |archivedate=October 3, 2013 |df=mdy }} He entered a plea of not guilty to all twelve counts.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} On January 23, 2013, a third indictment was filed against Brown on two counts of obstruction for concealing evidence during the March 6, 2012 FBI raid of his and his mother's homes.{{cite web|author=Anna Merlan |url=http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/unfairpark/2013/01/now_barrett_brown_is_being_cha.php |title=Barrett Brown Was Hit With a Third Indictment Yesterday, This Time For Concealing Evidence |work=Dallas Observer |date=January 24, 2013 |accessdate=September 6, 2013}} During a brief court hearing a week later, a judge found him [[Competence (law)|mentally competent to stand trial]], while Brown again pleaded not guilty to the additional charges.{{cite web|author=Anna Merlan |url=http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/unfairpark/2013/01/barrett_brown_found_competent.php |title=Barrett Brown Found Competent To Stand Trial; Pleads Not Guilty On Newest Charges of Concealing Evidence |work=Dallas Observer |date=January 30, 2013 |accessdate=September 6, 2013}} On May 1, 2013, it was announced that Brown had retained two attorneys, [[Charles Swift]] and [[Ahmed Ghappour]], to represent him in his legal cases.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} As of September 4, 2013, Brown was under a federal court-issued [[gag order]]; he and his lawyers were not allowed to discuss his case with the media, lest it taint a [[jury]].{{cite web|author=Fruzsina Eördögh |url=http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/the-us-government-just-upheld-barrett-browns-gag-order |title=The US Government Just Upheld Barrett Brown's Gag Order |publisher=Motherboard.vice.com |accessdate=September 6, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Robert Wilonsky|url=http://crimeblog.dallasnews.com/2013/09/hours-before-judge-hears-governments-case-to-slap-gag-on-jailed-hacktivist-barrett-brown-his-attorneys-strongly-object.html/ |title=Hours before judge hears government's case to slap gag on jailed hacktivist Barrett Brown, his attorneys strongly object |publisher=Dallas News |date=May 1, 2013 |accessdate=September 6, 2013}} [[Assistant United States Attorney]] Candina S. Heath (the lead prosecutor) said that Brown tried to manipulate the media from behind bars for his benefit, that Brown's attorney "coordinates and/or approves of his use of the media," and that most of the publicity about Brown has contained false information and "gross fabrications".{{Cite news|title=Gag order issued in federal cases against Dallas man tied to hacking group Anonymous|first=Kevin|last=Krause|date=September 4, 2013|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-news/20130904-gag-order-issued-in-federal-cases-against-man-tied-to-hacking-group-anonymous.ece}} Defense counsel maintained the gag order was an unfounded and unwarranted breach of Brown's First Amendment rights. Though forbidden to write or speak out about his case, Brown continued to pen articles from his prison cell on unrelated topics.{{cite web|author=Ed Pilkington |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/04/barrett-brown-gag-order-us-government |title=US stops jailed activist Barrett Brown from discussing leaks prosecution |work=The Guardian |date=September 4, 2013 |accessdate=December 27, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Tim Rogers|url=http://frontburner.dmagazine.com/2013/12/18/barrett-brown-writes-from-jail-about-profanity-on-the-airwaves/|title=Barrett Brown Writes From Jail About Profanity on the Airwaves|work=The Guardian |date=December 18, 2013|accessdate=December 27, 2013}} The gag order was lifted on April 23, 2014, and key documents were unsealed.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Brown had been [[Detention (imprisonment)|in custody]] since September 12, 2012.{{cite web|last=Zetter |first=Kim |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2013-01/25/barret-brown-charges |title=Anonymous spokesman Barrett Brown faces new charges |publisher=[[Wired UK]] |date=January 25, 2013 |accessdate=September 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109011851/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2013-01/25/barret-brown-charges |archivedate=November 9, 2013 |df=mdy }} His mother was sentenced on November 8, 2013, to six months of probation and a $1,000 fine for a misdemeanor charge of obstructing the execution of a search warrant. "My better judgment was clouded by my maternal instinct," she stated in court. The judge said to her, "I feel for you, as a parent. I know you did the best you could."{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/crime/headlines/20131108-mother-of-anonymous-linked-dallas-writer-gets-probation-for-hiding-laptops-from-feds.ece?nclick_check=1|title=Mother of Anonymous-linked Dallas writer gets probation for hiding laptops from feds|publisher=Dallas News |date=November 8, 2013 |accessdate=November 8, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Dart|first=Tom|title=Jailed activist Barrett Brown's mother given probation for helping son|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/nov/09/barrett-brown-anonymous-mother-probation|accessdate=December 27, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 9, 2013}} In March 2014, most charges against Brown were dropped.{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2014/03/feds-drop-most-charges-against-former-anon-spokesman/ |title=Feds drop most charges against former Anon spokesman|first= Joe |last=Mullin |date=March 5, 2014|accessdate=January 24, 2015}} In April 2014, it was reported that Brown had agreed to a [[Plea bargaining in the United States|plea bargain]].{{cite news|url=http://crimeblog.dallasnews.com/2014/12/dallas-journalist-barrett-brown-to-be-sentenced-in-federal-court-for-role-in-case-of-hacked-data.html/|title=Update: Dallas hacktivist Barrett Brown thought he would be sentenced today. He was wrong|newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|date=December 17, 2014|first=Kevin|last=Krause}} In January 2015, Brown was sentenced to 63 months in prison. He was also ordered to pay $890,250 in fines and restitution.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jan/22/barrett-brown-trial-warns-dangerous-precedent-hacking-sentencing |title=Barrett Brown sentenced to 63 months for 'merely linking to hacked material' |first=Nicky |last=Woolf |date=January 22, 2015 |work=The Guardian}} Journalist Janus Kopfstein said she believed the government considered Brown to be a threat and suggested that prosecutors made false allegations that were used to increase the length of his sentence.{{cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2015/2/will-matt-dehart-be-the-next-victim-of-the-war-on-leaks.html|title=Will Matt DeHart be the next victim of the war on leaks?|first=Janus|last=Kopfstein|date=February 25, 2015|publisher=[[Al Jazeera America]], [[Al Jazeera]]}} Supporting this theory, much of Brown's December sentencing hearing was spent in drawn-out arguments over the definitions of Project PM and Brown himself.{{cite news |url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2015/01/22/barrett-brown-sentenced-five-years-vows-keep-investigating-government-wrongdoing/ |title=Barrett Brown Sentenced to Five Years, Vows to Keep Investigating Government Wrongdoing |first=Michelle |last=Garcia |date=January 22, 2015 |accessdate=April 30, 2015 |work=[[The Intercept]]}}{{cite news |url=http://frontburner.dmagazine.com/2015/01/22/barrett-brown-sentenced-to-63-months-in-prison/ |title=Barrett Brown Sentenced to 63 Months In Prison |first=Zac |last=Crain |date=January 22, 2015 |accessdate=April 30, 2015 |work=[[D Magazine]]}} Brown was released from prison on November 29, 2016, and moved into a [[halfway house]] with five drug dealers close to downtown Dallas, Texas.{{cite web|author1=@FreeBarrett_|title=Free Barrett Brown on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/FreeBarrett_/status/803643430047916032|website=Twitter|accessdate=29 November 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.dmagazine.com/frontburner/2016/12/i-barrett-brown-have-returned/ |title=I, Barrett Brown, Have Returned |last=Brown |first=Barrett |date=1 December 2016 |website=D Magazine |publisher=D Magazine |access-date=2 December 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=Anonymous’ Barrett Brown Is Free—and Ready to Pick New Fights|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/12/anonymous-barrett-brown-free-ready-pick-new-fights/|accessdate=24 December 2016}} On April 27, 2017, Brown was arrested and held on unknown charges for four days.{{Cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2017/04/27/formerly-imprisoned-journalist-barrett-brown-taken-back-into-custody-before-pbs-interview/|title=Formerly Imprisoned Journalist Barrett Brown Taken Back Into Custody Before PBS Interview|last=Emmons2017-04-27T17:59:41+00:00|first=Alex EmmonsAlex|website=The Intercept|access-date=2017-04-28}} After he was released, he gave an interview to ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' while under [[house arrest]], despite pressure from the government not to speak to the media.{{cite news|last1=Goodman|first1=Amy|title=Jailed Reporter Barrett Brown on Press Freedom, FBI Crimes & Why He Wouldn't Do Anything Differently|url=https://www.democracynow.org/2017/5/12/jailed_reporter_barrett_brown_on_press|accessdate=May 14, 2017|work=Democracy Now!|date=May 12, 2017}} Brown has expressed a desire to move to Iceland or Germany when possible, telling ''[[Truthout]]'' in an interview, " I can't stay in the US because I can't get work done if I'm always subject to these little gusts of bureaucracy, which I am. It won't be for another year or so. I'm on probation for another two years. That generally goes down to one year if you don't act up. So in a year from now I'll be in a position to leave." == Surveillance of contacts and sympathizers == In 2017, lawyers for donors to Brown's legal fund filed suit{{cite web|url=https://freebarrettbrown.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Barrett-Brown-donors-complaint.pdf|title=Class-action complaint for violation of right to speak and associate anonymously under the first amendment of the United States Constitution; the Stored Communications Act; and the California constitutional right to privacy: demand for jury trial|author=Sheppard, Mullin, Richter & Hampton LLP|date=2017-02-06}} against Assistant United States Attorney Candina Heath for filing a subpoena against [[WePay]] that resulted in divulgence of their identities. The lawyers argued that the irrelevance of donor information to the case against Brown and the provision of the information directly to Special Agent Robert Smith of the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] rather than to the prosecutor or judge in the trial led to donors' belief that the information was intended to surveil and harass the donors for activity protected by the U.S. constitution, and filed for destruction of the data and monetary damages.{{cite web|url=https://freebarrettbrown.org/2017/05/12/us-government-moves-to-dismiss-our-lawsuit/|title=US government moves to dismiss our lawsuit on behalf of donors|publisher=The Courage Foundation}}{{cite web|url=http://www.truth-out.org/opinion/item/40779-we-don-t-have-the-rule-of-law-barrett-brown-on-incarceration-journalism-and-his-next-steps|title="We Don't Have the Rule of Law": Barrett Brown on Incarceration, Journalism and His Next Steps|author=Candice Bernd|publisher=Truth-out.org|date=2017-06-03}} On October 2, 2017, Judge Maria Elena James denied a motion to dismiss the case introduced by the Department of Justice.{{Cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/10/judge-barrett-brown-donors-can-sue-government-over-subpoenaed-records/|title=Judge: Barrett Brown donors can sue government over subpoenaed records|last=Farivar|first=Cyrus|date=October 4, 2017|work=Ars Technica|access-date=October 6, 2017}} In his sentencing statement, Brown alleged that, despite the denial of a subpoena by the judge to which he was making the statement, the identities of all contributors to the echelon2.org public [[Wiki]] had been obtained "by other means", and that "now the dozens of people who have given their time and expertise to what has been hailed by journalists and advocacy groups as a crucial journalistic enterprise are now at risk of being indicted under the same sort of spurious charges that I was facing not long ago, when the government exposed me to decades of prison time for copying and pasting a link to a publicly available file that other journalists were also linking to without being prosecuted."{{cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2015/01/22/read-the-statement-barrett-bro.html|title=Read the statement Barrett Brown read to the court in his sentencing hearing|publisher=BoingBoing.net|date=2015-01-22|author=Xeni Jardin}} ''[[The Intercept]]'', which had published award-winning work by Brown, was served with a subpoena{{cite web|url=https://mobile.twitter.com/couragefound/status/880856488918626305/photo/1|title=Subpoena|publisher=Courage Foundation|date=2017-06-30 |accessdate=2017-07-02}} ''(cited in the mintpressnews reference)'' for copies of "all contracts and/or agreements with", "any payments made to or for the benefit of", and "all correspondence to and from" Barrett Brown. Brown wrote, "the idea is that they are checking to see if I have money from the Intercept that I haven’t reported"; however, he also indicated that the Department of Justice might be seeking to dissuade publishers from giving him a platform.{{cite web|url=https://www.mintpressnews.com/barrett-brown-justice-department-subpoenaed-intercept-records/229331/|title=Barrett Brown: Justice Department Subpoenaed The Intercept For Records on Him|publisher=MintPress News|date=2017-07-01|author=Kevin Gosztola}} ==In the press and the arts== ''Relatively Free'' is a documentary film released in 2016 by Field of Vision about Brown's drive across Texas to a halfway house after he was released from prison.{{cite AV media | language = english | year = 2016 |title= Field of Vision - Relatively Free |url= https://vimeo.com/196463287 | access-date = 2016-01-28 }} Barrett Brown's case was included as a [[plot point]] in Season 2 of the U.S. TV series ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bdcwire.com/who-is-barrett-brown-and-why-is-house-of-cards-talking-about-him/|title=Why is Barrett Brown being mentioned on 'House of Cards'?|last=Pearlman|first=Alex|date=18 February 2014|work=BDCWire|access-date=2016-12-23|via=}} Brown serves on the [[advisory board]] of the [[International Modern Media Institute]].{{Cite web|url=https://en.immi.is/advisory-board/|title=Advisory Board|last=|date=|website=|publisher=International Modern Media Institute|access-date=2016-12-23}} ==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Freedom of speech]] * [[Hacktivist]] * [[Prior restraint]] * [[Streisand effect]] * [[Surveillance state]] }} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/mar/21/barrett-brown-persecution-anonymous The persecution of Barrett Brown – and how to fight it] [[Glenn Greenwald]], ''The Guardian''. 2013-03-21. * [http://www.democracynow.org/2013/7/11/jailed_journalist_barrett_brown_faces_105 Jailed Journalist Barrett Brown Faces 105 Years For Reporting on Hacked Private Intelligence Firms] ''[[Democracy Now!]]''. 2013-07-11. * {{cite news|title=Amerikansk journalist risikerer over 100 år i fengsel|url=http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/uriks/Amerikansk-journalist-risikerer-over-100-ar-i-fengsel-7304845.html|newspaper=[[Aftenposten]]|date=September 9, 2013|language=Norwegian}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Barrett Brown}} {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb name|5524714}} * {{caselaw source | case = United States v. [[Jackie Deveraux]] | cousins = | relatives = }} '''Blake Alexander Carrington''' is a [[fictional character]] on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television series ''[[Dynasty (1981 TV series)|Dynasty]]'', created by [[Richard and Esther Shapiro]]. The role was portrayed by [[John Forsythe]] from the [[Oil (Dynasty)|1981 pilot episode]] until the series finale in 1989. Forsythe returned for the 1991 [[miniseries]] ''[[Dynasty: The Reunion]]''. In [[The CW]]'s [[Dynasty (2017 TV series)|2017 reboot of the series]], Blake is played by [[Grant Show]]. Patriarch of the [[Carrington family]], self-made CEO of monolithic Denver-Carrington, and the principal character of the series, oil tycoon Blake Carrington is initially a ruthless man in both business and family matters. The character soon softens into a more benevolent patriarchal figure due to the influence of actor Forsythe. {{TOClimit|3}} ==Original series== ===Appearances=== Forsythe originated the role of Blake, playing the character from the first episode of the series in 1981 until its finale in 1989.{{Cite book |last=Schemering |first=Christopher |authorlink=Christopher Schemering |title=[[The Soap Opera Encyclopedia (Schemering book)|The Soap Opera Encyclopedia]] |date=September 1985 |pages=80–81 |isbn=0-345-32459-5}}{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/04/02/AR2010040202419.html| title=John Forsythe dead; starred in ''Dynasty'', ''Bachelor Father''| first=Adam| last=Bernstein| work=[[The Washington Post]]| date=April 3, 2010| accessdate=December 9, 2017}} He returned for the 1991 [[miniseries]], ''Dynasty: The Reunion''.{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20115641,00.html|title=Alexis Strikes Again!|last=Gliatto|first=Tom|first2=Vicki |last2=Sheff|date=August 5, 1991|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=Vol. 36, No. 4|pages=66–68|accessdate=February 21, 2009}} Forsythe is the only actor to appear in every episode of the series. [[George Peppard]] was originally cast as Blake, but ultimately had difficulties dealing with the somewhat unsympathetic role and was replaced with Forsythe.{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimatedynasty.net/autorizedbio.html |title=Portraying of Characters: Casting (Excerpt of Aaron Spelling/Douglas S. Cramer interview) |last=Hack |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Hack |date= |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=UltimateDynasty.net |accessdate=February 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328064017/http://www.ultimatedynasty.net/autorizedbio.html |archivedate=March 28, 2010 |df= }} ===Storylines=== ====Season one==== In the series premiere, Denver oil tycoon Blake Carrington marries his secretary [[Krystle Carrington|Krystle Jennings]]. Their marriage is strained by her discomfort as she learns about Blake's ruthless side, especially in business. Blake forces himself on Krystle when she is reluctant to have sex with him. Blake struggles with his daughter [[Fallon Carrington Colby|Fallon]]'s promiscuity and his son [[Steven Carrington|Steven]]'s homosexuality. He catches his son in an embrace with another man, and in a fit of anger pushes them apart. Steven's lover falls, hits his head, and dies. Blake is arrested and charged with murder. In the season finale, a mysterious witness enters the courtroom. Fallon identifies the woman as her mother. ====Season two==== Mystery witness [[Alexis Colby|Alexis Carrington]], Blake's ex-wife and Fallon and Steven's mother, testifies to Blake's violent temper. He is found guilty, but given a suspended sentence. While Blake struggles to save Denver-Carrington from financial troubles, he is thrilled to learn that Krystle is pregnant. Krystle loses her baby in a horse riding accident caused by Alexis. Blake suggests that Krystle meet with his friend, psychiatrist Nick Toscanni, unaware that Nick is seeking revenge against him. Later, Blake is blinded after mobster Logan Rhinewood bombs his car. Blake come to suspect that Krystle is having an affair with Nick, so after his sight returns he continues to feign blindness in order spy on her. In the season finale, he confronts Nick, who leaves an unconscious Blake for dead on a remote mountainside. ====Season three==== Krystle finds Blake and gets him help. Later Blake learns that Fallon's son, his namesake [[L.B. Colby|"Little Blake" Colby]], has been kidnapped. Blake and Alexis make a televised plea for the return of their infant grandson, and on-air Alexis confesses a dark secret from their past: their firstborn son, [[Adam Carrington|Adam]], had been kidnapped as a baby and was never recovered. Traumatized by the event, they had hidden his existence from their subsequent children Fallon and Steven. Weeks later, attorney Michael Torrance from [[Billings, Montana]] approaches Blake and claims to be Adam. Though Alexis believes him, Blake does not, but he eventually accepts Adam as his son. Blake and Krystle learn that her divorce from her first husband was never filed. Their relationship deteriorates, until Blake and Krystle separate. Steven is missing and presumed dead in an oil rig explosion, but Blake refuses to believe that his son is dead. When Steven's ex-wife [[Sammy Jo Carrington|Sammy Jo]], Krystle's neice, appears with a baby that she says is Steven's, Blake offers to keep the child. Later, he learns that Steven is alive, and flies to Singapore to convince him to return to Denver. In the third season finale, Blake learns that Steven is living with another man, and decides to sue for custody of his grandson. ====Season four==== Blake loses his custody fight when Steven marries [[Claudia Blaisdel Carrington|Claudia Blaisdel]]. However, father and son reconcile when Blake and Krystle remarry. Still seeking revenge, Alexis enlists [[Rashid Ahmed]] to sabotage a deal he has with Blake. Blake is broken. ====Season five==== Blake manages to save his company, but he mourns Fallon's death in a plane crash. Blake also learns that he has an illegitimate half-sister, [[Dominique Deveraux]]. He accepts his sister after his father, [[Tom Carrington (Dynasty character)|Tom Carrington]], admits on his deathbed that she is his daughter. A few months later, Blake learns that Alexis had another child after they divorced, a daughter she named [[Amanda Carrington|Amanda]]. Although Alexis initially denies that he is Amanda's father, Blake eventually learns that she is, in fact, his daughter. At Christmas, Blake is thrilled when Krystle has a baby girl they name [[Krystina Carrington|Krystina]]. Although her health is fragile at first, she survives and thrives. Blake grows jealous of Krystle's friendship with playboy [[Daniel Reece (character)|Daniel Reece]]. Meanwhile, Lady [[Ashley Mitchell (character)|Ashley Mitchell]] attempts to seduce Blake. Someone has photos taken of both Blake with Ashley and Krystle with Daniel, and sends them to the other spouse. However, Blake and Krystle declare their love for each other. The entire family attends the wedding of Amanda and Prince [[Michael of Moldavia]], and rebels storm the chapel and spray the church with bullets. ====Season six==== Blake and his family survive the attack. Upon returning to Denver, Blake enters a business deal with [[Jason Colby]], and is shocked to discover that Fallon is alive, suffering from amnesia, and married to Jason's son, [[Miles Colby|Miles]]. Krystle is kidnapped by [[Joel Abrigore]] and replaced with a look-alike named [[Rita Lesley]], who slowly poisons him on Joel's orders. Blake's health deteriorates until he is almost completely incapacitated. Sammy Jo learns the truth and helps Krystle escape captivity. Joel and Rita disappear. Blake is furious when his brother [[Ben Carrington|Ben]] returns to Denver. In league with Alexis, Ben sues for his share of their late father's estate. Blake mortgages his house and holdings, expecting to gain control over ColbyCo. Thanks to Ben and Alexis's interference, he loses everything, including his lucrative South China Sea oil leases. In the season finale, he learns that Alexis has bought his house. Furious, he grabs her by the throat and starts to strangle her. ====Season seven==== Krystle pulls Blake off of Alexis. Blake learns that his hotel, La Mirage, has burned down and that several people, including Claudia, have perished in the fire. Blake is charged with arson, but eventually the charges are dropped when it is revealed that Claudia was responsible for the blaze. As Blake continues to try and regain his empire, he discovers that the land he inherited from his mother is rich in natural gas. However, he is forced to temporarily halt his plans to develop on the land when Alexis and Ben learn of its existence. Soon after, [[Emily Fallmont]] gives incriminating information about Alexis and Ben to Blake, who uses it to force them to relinquish their ownership of Denver-Carrington and all its holdings back to him, including the South China Sea oil leases. Later, Blake, Alexis, and Ben are in southeast Asia inspecting an oil rig when it catches fire. Ben rescues a trapped Blake moments before the rig explodes. Blake awakens in the hospital with no memories of the last 25 years. Alexis has him discharged from the hospital and convinces him that they are still married. However, when Krystle finds them, Blake's memories return. Blake and Krystle's daughter, Krystina, falls ill and needs a heart transplant. A donor is found and Krystina is saved, but the donor's mother, [[Sarah Curtis (Dynasty character)|Sarah Curtis]], kidnaps Krystina. She is later recovered, unharmed. In the season finale, Blake and Alexis legally adopt Adam. ====Season eight==== Blake runs for governor, opposed by the incumbent and Alexis. After a long and grueling campaign, both he and Alexis lose. Not long after, Blake returns home to find his bedroom in disarray and Krystle missing. He says, "Oh, Krystle, I thought we had more time!" ====Season nine==== Krystle has a serious brain tumor and must have risky surgery. They fly to Switzerland, where the surgery is successful, but Krystle is left in a coma. A body is found at the bottom of a lake on the Carrington property. It turns out to be Roger Grimes, the man with whom Alexis was having the affair that caused her and Blake's divorce. Roger has been dead for 20 years, but the cold temperatures in the lake preserved his body. Ultimately, it is revealed that 8-year-old Fallon had shot Roger after finding him beating Alexis, and Blake's late father Tom had hidden the body in a mine under the lake to protect Fallon. The situation is complicated by the fact that the mine is full of stolen Nazi treasure, hidden there by Tom. In the last episode of the series, Blake learns that the police captain investigating Roger's murder is searching for the treasure. Blake attempts to force a confession. The captain pulls a gun, and they both shoot. Blake is left lying in a pool of blood. ====''The Reunion''==== Three years later, in ''[[Dynasty: The Reunion]]'' (1991), Blake has fully recovered from his gunshot injury and is being released from jail after being exonerated for the fatal shooting of Captain Handler. Along with his sons, Steven and Adam, and former son-in-law [[Jeff Colby]], Blake attempts to regain control of Denver-Carrington from an international consortium. Krystle returns, having come out of her coma, but has been programmed by the Consortium to assassinate Blake. Her love for Blake proves to be too strong, and breaks the Consortium's control over her. ==Reboot== A [[television pilot|pilot]] for a [[Dynasty (2017 TV series)|''Dynasty'' reboot]] for [[The CW]] was announced in September 2016,{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/dynasty-reboot-works-at-cw-934334 |title=''Dynasty'' Reboot in the Works at The CW |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |first1=Lesley |last1=Goldberg |first2=Michael |last2=O'Connell |date=September 30, 2016 |accessdate=October 6, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2016/09/dynasty-reboot-the-cw-josh-schwartz-stephanie-savage-1201829178/ |title=''Dynasty'' Reboot Set At the CW With Josh Schwartz & Stephanie Savage |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=September 30, 2016 |accessdate=October 2, 2016}} and [[Grant Show]] was cast as Blake in March 2017.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/dynasty-grant-show-star-blake-carrington-the-cw-reboot-1202034650/ |title=''Dynasty'': Grant Show To Star As Blake Carrington In The CW Reboot Pilot |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=March 2, 2017 |accessdate=March 3, 2017}} The new series premiered on The CW on October 11, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/the-cw-fall-premiere-dates-dynasty-valor-the-flash-1202109659/|title=The CW Sets Fall 2017 Premiere Dates For ''Dynasty'' & ''Valor'' And Returning Series|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=June 8, 2017|accessdate=June 8, 2017}} ===Characterization=== Executive producer [[Josh Schwartz]] said that, according to series creator [[Esther Shapiro]], "Blake Carrington was a guy who could run this amazing company, but the one place that he really struggles is running his own family."{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/10/11/dynasty-reboot-preview/|title=''Dynasty'' producers talk reimagining the beloved primetime soap|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|first=Samantha|last=Highfill|date=October 11, 2017|accessdate=November 15, 2018}} Showrunner [[Sallie Patrick]] described Blake as "a white patriarch who is in a changing world".{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-ca-st-fall-preview-dynasty-reboot-lessons-20170908-htmlstory.html|title=The do's and don'ts of reboots: ''Dynasty'' edition|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Yvonne|last=Villarreal|date=September 8, 2017|accessdate=October 19, 2017}} She noted, "I love Grant Show's warmth when he lies directly to his son's face about having returned the phone. That's just one of the skills that make Blake Carrington the multi-billion dollar magnate that he is."{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/10/25/dynasty-episode-3-blog-sallie-patrick/|title=''Dynasty'' showrunner takes you behind the scenes of that drama-filled gala|work=Entertainment Weekly|first=Sallie|last=Patrick|date=October 25, 2017|accessdate=November 9, 2017}} Show said, "Blake Carrington is not just your average soap opera character. He's very complex. He's a protagonist, but a very flawed protagonist. I was intrigued by that."{{cite web|url=https://people.com/tv/grant-show-melrose-place-dynasty/|title='90s Heartthrob Grant Show Reveals Which ''Melrose Place'' Costar He'd Love to Reunite with|work=People|first=Dana Rose|last=Falcone|date=October 6, 2017|accessdate=October 28, 2018}} ===Reception=== Maureen Ryan of ''Variety'' called Grant Show "personable and charismatic" in the role, but noted that "a few corporate moves that are meant to make Blake seem deviously brilliant make him look anything but." She added, "If you’re going to base a show around the machinations of a brilliant and ruthless mastermind, his strokes of genius should seem whipsmart and diabolically genius, not predictable or even puzzling."{{cite web|url=http://variety.com/2017/tv/reviews/dynasty-review-cw-reboot-1202584620/|title=TV Review: ''Dynasty'' Reboot on The CW|first=Maureen|last=Ryan|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=October 9, 2017|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Dynasty}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carrington, Blake}} [[Category:Male characters in television]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1981]] [[Category:Dynasty (TV series) characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Colorado]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Fictional rapists]] [[Category:Fictional murderers]] [[Category:Fictional business executives]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Carl McCoy | background = solo_singer | image = Carl McCoy-FotN.jpg | caption = Carl McCoy, WGT 2008 | birth_name = Carl McCoy | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|1|18|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[London]], United Kingdom | genre = [[Gothic rock]], [[gothic metal]], [[death metal]], [[industrial metal]] | occupation = Musician
Graphic designer | years_active = 1984–present | label = [[Beggars Banquet Records|Beggars Banquet]], [[Jungle Records]], [[Situation Two Records]], [[Sacred Symphony]] | associated_acts = [[Fields of the Nephilim]]
[[Nefilim]] | website = [http://www.fields-of-the-nephilim.com/ www.fields-of-the-nephilim.com] }} '''Carl McCoy''' (born 18 January 1963, [[Lambeth]], [[London]], England){{cn|date=April 2016}} is the [[frontman]] for [[gothic rock]] band [[Fields of the Nephilim]]. ==Biography== The band formed in 1984. Following on from two [[Extended play|EP]]s, their first album ''[[Dawnrazor]]'' was released in 1987. They produced two more full-length albums, ''[[The Nephilim (album)|The Nephilim]]'' and ''[[Elizium]]'', plus a live album called ''[[Earth Inferno]]'' and a handful of singles, before splitting in 1991. McCoy went on to form [[Nefilim]]. The 1996 release of Nefilim's album ''[[Zoon]]'' saw a departure from the ethereal gothic sound of ''Elizium'' in favour of an [[industrial metal]] and [[death metal]] direction. McCoy's most recent studio album, ''[[Mourning Sun]]'', was released in 2005. Although it was released under the name [[Fields of the Nephilim]], McCoy has been secretive about the musicians who play on ''Mourning Sun'', with John 'Capachino' Carter the only named contributor. The album was conceived and produced in McCoy's studio. McCoy frequently uses mystical and [[occult]] references in his lyrics. Samples of [[Aleister Crowley]]'s voice were featured on ''Elizium''; one of Fields of the Nephilim's biggest hits, "Moonchild", shares a name with one of Crowley's [[Moonchild (novel)|novels]]. In interviews, McCoy has hinted that he sees his on-stage performances as theurgic, [[Witchcraft|magickal]] or [[shamanic]] workings.{{Cite web|title = The Quietus {{!}} Features {{!}} A Quietus Interview {{!}} Into The Subconscious: Fields Of The Nephilim Interviewed|url = http://thequietus.com/articles/08546-fields-of-the-nephilim-interview|website = The Quietus|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}{{Citation needed|date=November 2015}} He is also an admirer of [[Austin Osman Spare]] (the name of the Fields of the Nephilim live album ''Earth Inferno'' comes from one of Spare's works) and has thanked "AOS" in dedications on his albums. In another nod to [[chaos magic]], Fields of the Nephilim's song ''[[Psychonaut]]'' shares its name with a book on the subject by [[Peter J. Carroll]], and quotes lines from the ''[[Necronomicon]]''. McCoy's lyrics are heavily influenced by the work of [[H. P. Lovecraft]], and mention [[Cthulhu Mythos|Cthulhu]] in several places. McCoy owns a graphics company, Sheerfaith, which has supplied art and design for all of his musical projects. Sheerfaith has also produced artwork for other projects, such as for the [[Storm Constantine]] book ''Hermetech'' and Andrew Collins' ''21st Century Grail''. He himself is a 3D artist, a longtime user of [[LightWave 3D]].http://sumerland.devin.com/articles/sheerfaith-computerarts.shtml McCoy appeared as the nomad in the motion picture ''[[Hardware (film)|Hardware]]'' (1990), directed by [[Richard Stanley (film director)|Richard Stanley]],[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0566710/ IMDB page on McCoy] who had previously directed a number of videos for Fields of the Nephilim. ==Personal life== McCoy has two daughters, Scarlett and Eden, with his long-time partner Lynn. The Nephilim's 1996 album ''Zoon'' was dedicated to Scarlett. Both girls sing on ''Mourning Sun''. McCoy comes from a religious background; he grew up in England with his mother, who was deeply religious, a [[Jehovah's Witness]]. McCoy later dealt with his relation to Christianity critically in some of his songs such as "Chord of Souls".Baddeley: Goth Chic. 2002 He has talked in interviews about his belief in [[paganism]].https://books.google.com/books?id=bB8D1Fm2G4kC&pg=PA35 ==Discography== {{Main|Fields of the Nephilim#Discography}} {{Main|Nefilim#Discography}} * [[Watain]] - ''[[Lawless Darkness]]'' (2010, guest vocals) ==References== {{BLP sources|date=March 2009}} {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *Baddeley, Gavin: ''Goth Chic: A Connoisseur's Guide to Dark Culture'' (Plexus, 2002) *{{Cite news | url=http://www.alternative-zine.com/interviews/en/60 | accessdate=10 March 2009 | publisher=''Alternative-Zine'' | date=23 November 2005 | title=Interview with: Carl McCoy ... }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McCoy, Carl}} [[Category:Gothic rock musicians]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English male singers]] [[Category:Occultists]] [[Category:People from Lambeth]] [[Category:British neopagans]] [[Category:English people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Performers of neopagan music]]

{{For|others of a similar name|David Brown (disambiguation){{!}}David Brown}} {{Infobox baseball biography |name=Dave Brown |image=1923 Tomas Gutierrez Dave Brown.jpg |caption= |position=[[Pitcher]] |bats=Left |throws=Left |birth_date={{Birth date|1895|6|9}} |birth_place=[[Leon County, Texas]]<ref name="draftrego">[http://negroleagues.bravehost.com/pdf/002272.pdf "Dave Brown's WWI Draft Registration, City Secretary, Dallas, Texas, June 4, 1917"]</ref> |death_date= |death_place= |debutyear=1917 |debutteam=[[Dallas Black Giants]] |finalyear=1926 |finalteam=Gilkerson's Union Giants |statleague=Negro league |stat1label=[[Win–loss record (pitching)|Win–loss record]] |stat1value=45–22 |stat2label=[[Earned run average]] |stat2value=3.23 |stat3label=[[Strikeout]]s |stat3value=336 |teams= * Dallas Black Giants ({{baseball year|1917}}–{{baseball year|1918}}) * [[Chicago American Giants]] ({{baseball year|1919}}–{{baseball year|1922}}) * [[New York Lincoln Giants]] ({{baseball year|1923}}–{{baseball year|1925}}) | highlights = }}
'''David Brown''' (born June 9, 1895)<ref name="statistics">[https://www.baseball-reference.com/nlb/player.cgi?id=brown-008dav "Dave Brown Negro League Statistics & History"]. baseball-reference.com. Retrieved June 8, 2012.</ref><ref name="draftrego" /> was a left-handed [[pitcher]] in [[Negro league baseball]]. Considered one of the better pitchers in negro league history, he was also known for serious off-the-field problems. His career came to a premature end when he became a fugitive after allegedly killing a man in 1925.
==Early career== Brown was born in [[Leon County, Texas]].<ref name="statistics"/> He had a good [[curveball]] and excellent control. He was also a good fielder and had outstanding speed but was a weak hitter. Brown played with the Dallas Black Giants in 1917 and 1918.<ref name="Dallas1918">[http://negroleagues.bravehost.com/pdf/001945.pdf "Plenty of Baseball Provided for Fans of Dallas Today" Dallas Morning News, Dallas, Texas, Sunday, August 11, 1918, Page 8, Column 2]</ref> He was regarded as a "timid nice guy" who did not cause trouble, but during his time with the [[Dallas Black Giants]] he was involved in a highway [[robbery]].<ref name="Riley117">Riley, p. 117.</ref> Although Brown was reported to have become a fugitive, [[Rube Foster]] agreed to pay $20,000 for Brown's [[parole]] and he became a member of Foster's [[Chicago American Giants]].<ref name="Riley117" /><ref name="Cottrell165">Cottrell, p. 165.</ref>
==Chicago American Giants Seasons==
[[File:Chicago American Giants 1919.jpg|left|thumb|230px|1919 Chicago American Giants]] Brown became the [[ace (baseball)|ace]] of the American Giants as they dominated negro league baseball in the early 1920s. From 1920 through 1922, he posted a 29-8 [[Win (baseball)|record]] in league games.<ref name="Riley117" /> His 11-3 record led them to a pennant win in 1921 including three victories in a playoff with the [[Bacharach Giants]].<ref name="Riley117" /><ref name="Cottrell160">Cottrell, p. 160.</ref> His 8-3 record contributed to another pennant in 1922.<ref name="Cottrell163">Cottrell, p. 163.</ref> In the winter following the 1922 season, Brown joined [[Oscar Charleston]] for the first season of the [[Cuban League]]'s [[Santa Clara Leopardos]].<ref name="Heaphy1734">Heaphy, pp. 173-174.</ref>
==League change and abrupt career end== For the 1923 season, Brown left Rube Foster's American Giants for the brand new [[Eastern Colored League]]. Foster voiced his displeasure, pointing out that Brown had been paroled to him and that he had promised Brown's mother to take care of him. He pointed out that the public would vilify him if he revoked.<ref name="Cottrell165">Cottrell, p. 165.</ref> Brown posted a losing record in his first season with the [[New York Lincoln Giants]] but he and Charleston returned to Cuba the following winter and helped Santa Clara compile one of the best records in Cuban baseball history.<ref name="Riley118">Riley, p. 118.</ref><ref name="Heaphy174">Heaphy, p. 174.</ref> His second season with the Lincoln Giants improved on the first and he defeated "Cannonball" [[Dick Redding]] and the [[Brooklyn Royal Giants]] to win the [[New York City]] championship.<ref name="Riley117" />
Brown's career came to an abrupt end in 1925. He went to a bar one night with [[Frank Wickware]] and [[Oliver Marcelle]].<ref name="Riley118" /><ref name="James184">James, p. 184.</ref> Marcelle was a [[third baseman]] with a reputation for trouble off the field.<ref name="James184" /> A fight erupted at the bar, possibly involving [[cocaine]], and Brown killed one of the participants {Benjamin Adair} <ref>[https://www.bing.com/images/search?view=detailV2&ccid=xuRyoXXZ&id=1FED3D391F21EF77D788FA6F811D417EE2C683BF&thid=OIP.xuRyoXXZvKBzpI0ir5FOzAHaGf&mediaurl=http%3a%2f%2fcardsthatneverwere.com%2fwp-content%2fuploads%2flefty-brown.jpg&exph=1173&expw=1339&q=Wanted++Poster+Lefty+Dave+Brown&simid=608036985236556903&selectedIndex=1&ajaxhist=0 Cards that never were]</ref> April 27,1925<ref>[The League of Outsider Baseball: An Illustrated History of Baseball's ...By Gary Cieradkowski pp. 128-129]</ref>. Wickware and Marcelle were questioned the next day at the ballpark, but Brown had disappeared.<ref name="Riley118" />
==Rumors and legacy== The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] searched for Brown but he was never officially seen again. Rumors abounded that he continued playing baseball under the alias "Lefty Wilson" with [[semi-professional]] teams through the [[Midwestern United States]]. Lefty Wilson toured with [[Gilkerson's Union Giants]] in 1926,<ref name="gilkerson1926">[https://docs.google.com/open?id=0B1Wcncq5-bHdVWFYMENhekRMUVk "Gilkerson Union Giants Swamp Knights of Columbus Nine 11 to 4" Davenport Democrat and Leader, Davenport, IA, Monday Evening, June 21, 1926, Page 7, Columns 1 and 2]</ref> a white team in [[Bertha, Minnesota]] in 1927 and 1928, and he was rumored to have played in [[Sioux City, Iowa]] in 1929 and [[Little Falls, Minnesota]] in 1930. More unsubstantiated rumors claimed that Brown died in mysterious circumstances in [[Denver, Colorado]] in 1930.<ref name="Riley118" /> However, Lefty Wilson shows up again pitching for the [[Gilkerson's Union Giants]] again in 1932. Reportedly, he was alive in 1938 <ref>[See The League of Outsider Baseball: An Illustrated History of Baseball's ...By Gary Cieradkowski p.129 for a 1938 report of Brown]</ref>.
In 1927, a ''[[Pittsburgh Courier]]'' column solicited opinions for the best black baseball player of all time. On April 2, [[John Henry Lloyd]] announced his list which included Dave Brown.<ref name="Cottrell175">Cottrell, p. 175.</ref> When the ''Pittsburgh Courier'' announced a similar list in 1952, they included Brown on their second team.<ref name="Cottrell182">Cottrell, p. 182.</ref>
